dataset.title: Census - Spartina Production. Spartina alterniflora production: Goat Island high marsh nitrogen fertilizer and control. Oyster Landing high and low marsh.

para.literalLayout: The long term study of Spartina alterniflora in salt marsh ecosystems. Specifically, the measurement of biomass, production, and stem density in various marsh sites to understand long-term patterns of Spartina growth and to relate these patterns to other factors in the LTER study.

geographicCoverage.geographicDescription: North Inlet encompasses about 2,630 hectares of tidal marshes and wetlands near Georgetown, South Carolina, USA. North Inlet-Winyah Bay features high quality, ocean-dominated waters and salt marshes in North Inlet, contrasting with the brackish waters and marshes of Winyah Bay. The bay estuary is dominated by riverine discharges from a watershed impacted by agricultural, municipal and industrial development. Former rice fields and canals provide another system for study within the Reserve. The Debidue site is located at the confluence of Town Creek and Debidue Creek. The Bread and Butter site is located along the western shoreline of Town Creek adjacent to the mouth of Clambank Creek. GI is in the marsh east of Goat Island. It is accessible from Clambank Rd. about 1/4 mile from the firetower. A board walk connects the high marsh site and the low marsh site. OL is in the Oyster Landing basin. The high marsh site is located on the north side of the road which leads to the landing. The low marsh site lies between the boardwalk to the MET station and the small channel to the boat landing. GI is the older marsh site: the marsh sediments are about 50 cm deep, Organic content is somewhat higher, and it is closer to the ocean than OL. OL is a young marsh near the forest and close to a stream which drains a small forested watershed after big rainfalls. Salinities are often, but not always lower at OL. Spartina stem densities are lower at OL than at GI but annual production at the two sites is similar.

para.literalLayout: See publication: Ecology, 71(6), 1990, Morris and Haskin.

each study site three plots (1.2 m x 1.2 m) were laid out. Inside each plot there were two subplots in which all stems were tagged. The stems were censused monthly and biomass and production were calculated. At Goat Island there were 3 nitrogen fertilized plots in addition to the 3 control plots.

Plant heights (the raw data) were converted to biomass by a series of algorithms. The equations were derived from seasonal harvests of hundreds of Spartina stems. Production was calculated for each plot by summing all the individual increases in stem biomass within the plot.

textDomain.definition: Plot and Subplot identifier codes . For the first two digits 5,9,12 are control plots and plots 2,13,14 are nitrogen fertilized. The second two digits represent the subplot.

attribute.attributeDefinition: Indentifier for the plant: is 12 digit with a decimal between the first 6 and the second six. The first 6 digits specify the parent of a stem if it is known. The second 6 digits specify the stem.

textDomain.definition: Indentifier for the plant: is 12 digit with a decimal between the first 6 and the second six. The first 6 digits specify the parent of a stem if it is known. The second 6 digits specify the stem. Example: 117901.112302 Stems large enough to hold a band are tagged. Band color is indicated by the first digit: 1=red,2=blue,3=yellow,4=white,5=pink. Digits 2,3,4 are the band number (1-200). Digits 5 and 6 are the number of times the particular tag has been used. A sprout that is too small for a tag is identified (as in above example) by its parent and then is numbered 1,2,3 etc. for as many small sprouts as the parent has.
